title: Free time in Lisbon
text:
This page refers to an event that will take place on the 12th September
Suggestions for having a wander around Lisbon - neighborhoods, viewpoints, drinks and a spot of dinner
Lisbon is a city rich with winding streets, beautiful viewpoints in which to catch the sunset, and lovely bars and restaurants to stop for a drink and some nibbles. We leave you, then, with some suggestions and inspiration on what to do and where to go after the DTN Annual Forum.

title: Free time in Lisbon
text:
Alfama
Head up to Alfama, one of Europe‚Äôs oldest neighborhoods



Photo by Joao on Unsplash


There‚Äôs plenty to see and routes you can take (and wandering around is the best part!), but we would suggest starting your itinerary around the Igreja de Santo Ant√≥nio and the S√©. The Lisbon Cathedral is almost 9 centuries old, and from there you‚Äôre presented a choice - up the hill to Rua Augusto Rosa, or down the hill to Cruzes da S√©.
Uphill, climb up to the first viewpoint, Santa Luzia. If you‚Äôre already hungry, Alpendre is a great traditional restaurant on the way. If not, keep going until Portas do Sol, one of the most beautiful lookout points in the city. Stop awhile for a drink at The Terrace, climb a little further up to Rua das Escolas Gerais, and make your way to the Santo Estev√£o belvedere. There‚Äôs plenty of good restaurants around, but we‚Äôd suggest Lisboa Tu & Eu, A Morgadinha, Taberna Sal Grosso, and Sr.¬†Fado.
Downhill, have a stroll down Rua Cruzes da S√©, through the Largo de S√£o Miguel, down to the Largo do Chafariz de Dentro. Have a ginginha (sour cherry liqueur) and refer to the restaurant suggestions we‚Äôve mentioned above.

title: Free time in Lisbon
text:
Gra√ßa
Grab the funicular to beautiful and vibrant Gra√ßa



Photo by Anna Dziubinska on Unsplash


Lisbon is one of the Cities on Seven Hills, so we do have shortcuts! Take the funicular up to the Miradouro Sophia de Mello Breyner Andresen. Have a drink and a snack in one of the many caf√©s on the way to or on the main square (Largo da Gra√ßa) - we are partial to both Cabreira and Saga for some pastries and coffee. Then do climb further up to the Miradouro Senhora do Monte, Lisbon highest viewpoint, for a breathtaking sunset view.



Photo by TheDumpy on Wikimedia


For dinner, we recommend O Pit√©u da Gra√ßa, Via Gra√ßa, Sant‚ÄôAv√≥ and Taberna do Mar.

title: Free time in Lisbon
text:
Mouraria
Meander through Mouraria, the Moorish Quarter
Up the hill, but with two shortcuts! Take the first lift from Rua dos Fanqueiros to Largo Adelino Amaro da Costa and, if you‚Äôre already feeling peckish, treat yourself to one of the best sandwiches in town and have a bifana (pork sandwich) at Bifanas do Afonso. Then take the second lift inside Ch√£o de Loureiro and chill with a drink at the gorgeous viewpoint on top.
Come down the street to S√£o Cristov√£o, and have a wander around the streets and alleys of Mouraria - we recommend taking the stairs toLargo da Achada, then coming down to Beco das Farinhas to take a look at Tribute, a permanent photography exhibit featuring the neighborhood‚Äôs oldest residents. Make your way to Largo dos Trigueiros, with two excellent choices for some dining - O Corvo, and Cantinho do Aziz (for some excellent samosas). We also thoroughly recommend O Velho Eurico and Tasca Baldracca, both serving new twists on traditional portuguese fare.




Photo by Fabien Rousselot on Unsplash

title: Pitch & poster instructions
text:
This page refers to an event that will take place on the 10th September
As part of this year‚Äôs forum, some attendees will present a brief overview of their research. Please follow the instructions below to prepare your contribution.

title: Pitch & poster instructions
text:
üîπ 3-Minute Research Pitch
Prepare a 3-minute presentation highlighting your current or previous research.

You may use slides to support your pitch (PowerPoint or PDF format). Slides will be loaded in advance, so please do not plan to use your own laptop.

üìå Important!
Pitching is mandatory for all DTN members who have not presented in previous editions. If you have already pitched in a past forum, you are still very welcome to present again if you would like to share updates or new research.

title: Pitch & poster instructions
text:
üîπ A1 Poster (Portrait Orientation)
Design a poster (A1 size, portrait format) that visually communicates your research.

Be creative! The layout and content are up to you.

Mandatory: Please use the this template.

title: Pitch & poster instructions
text:
üì§ Submission
Deadline: August 25

To ensure a smooth setup and free printing of your poster, please submit both your slides and poster by email to: ‚úâÔ∏è mauricio.orozco@tecnico.ulisboa.pt

‚ö†Ô∏è Late submissions will not be printed, so please respect the deadline.

All posters will be displayed throughout the 3-day event ‚Äî make yours stand out!

title: Technical visits
text:
This page refers to an event that will take place on the 11th September
On the 2nd day afternoon, there will be technical visits to some mobility companies that operate in Potugal.

title: Technical visits
text: Carris is the public operator of Lisbon urban bus, tram and funicular services. Founded in 1872, it transports more than 130 million passengers every year.  This visit will take the participants to the operational control center and the buses workshop.  Schedule: 15:00 to 17:00 | Openings: 25 participants | Location: Miraflores garage

title: Technical visits
text:
All participants enrolled in the visit to Infraestruturas de Portugal must take an ID card or passport with them.

Infraestruturas de Portugal is the public company responsible for managing the Portuguese road and rail infrastructure.  In this visit, the participants will have the opportunity to get to know the Lisbon rail operational control center, managing most of the national infrastructure.  Schedule: 15:00 to 17:00 | Openings: 25 participants | Location: Lisbon Operational Control Center

title: Technical visits
text: GIRA is Lisbon‚Äôs public bike system. Operating since 2017, it already counts with 188 dock stations, that provide more than 2000 bicycles to live and explore the city.  The visit will allow the participants to explore the system control center and the bicycles workshop.  Schedule: 15:00 to 17:00 | Openings: 25 participants | Location: GIRA bike workshop

title: Technical visits
text:
TML is a public company 100% owned by the Lisbon Metropolitan Area (AML), a public association of 18 municipalities. It works as a transport authority with the main functions of ticketing manager for all modes under the brand Navegante, and bus service provider by subcontracting under Carris Metropolitana. It also has competences in the development, management, and operation of parking and mobility services. TML also studies, plans and implements mobility solutions.  In this visit, the participants will have the opportunity to get to know TML headquarters and visit the Carris Metropolitana operational control center.  Schedule: 15:00 to 17:00 | Openings: 25 participants | Location: TML headquarters







Carris bus and tram







Rail control center







GIRA bicycle







TML

title: 8-9th Sept.¬†| Tools and Skills for Reproducible Transport Research
text: Robin Lovelace (University of Leeds) & Juan Fonseca-Zamora (University of Leeds)

title: 8-9th Sept.¬†| Tools and Skills for Reproducible Transport Research
text: Robin Lovelace (University of Leeds) & Juan Fonseca-Zamora (University of Leeds)

title: 8-9th Sept.¬†| Tools and Skills for Reproducible Transport Research
text:
Location
 Room 2.1

title: 8-9th Sept.¬†| Tools and Skills for Reproducible Transport Research
text:
Learning objectives

Be able to share reproducible code for more scientific and transparent transport research
To be confident reproducing your own work and that of others
To become skilled at using Git and GitHub to manage versions of your code and collaborate with others
To be able to write reproducible content that can be exported to a variety of formats with the Quarto system for scientific publishing
To understand how Quarto extensions can be used as a basis for creating publication-ready papers
To be aware of ‚Äòcontinuous integration‚Äô and ‚ÄòGitHub Actions‚Äô and how they can be used to ensure reproducibility, share your work, and save time
Understanding of best practices around code sharing and collaboration for reproducible research in transport planning

title: 13-14th Sept.¬†| Qualitative Methods in Urban Mobility Research

text:
Location
 Room 2.2

title: 13-14th Sept.¬†| Qualitative Methods in Urban Mobility Research
text:
Learning objectives

Introduce doctoral researchers to the basic techniques of qualitative methods and provide knowledge on how to perform reproducible research.
Provide doctoral researchers with the skills to design research and data collection protocols.
Explain how technological transitions, such as the invention of GenAI, can affect qualitative research, and the implications for biases and ethics.

title: Jo√£o Paulo Costeira
text:
Jo√£o Paulo Costeira is an Associate Professor at the Instituto Superior T√©cnico (IST), University of Lisbon. He holds a Ph.D.¬†in Electrical and Computer Engineering from IST. He is a senior researcher with the Signal and Image Processing Group (SIPg) and has served as its group coordinator, where he conducts research in computer vision and robotics. He is a former co-director of the Dual Ph.D.¬†Program in Electrical and Computer Engineering and Robotics within the Carnegie Mellon | Portugal program. He also served as the Scientific Director of the Carnegie Mellon | Portugal initiative from 2014 to 2018.

 This speaker will host a keynote on the 10th September

title: Juan P. Fonseca-Zamora
text:
Juan P. Fonseca-Zamora is a PhD student enrolled in the 4-year integrated PhD and MSc programme in Data Analytics and Society at the Leeds Institute for Data Analytics (LIDA).
He previously completed an MSc in Transport Planning and the Environment at the Institute for Transport Studies, University of Leeds, and worked in industry as a transport planner for three years. During this time in consultancy, he developed a strong interest in the use of open resources to better understand and address transport challenges.
His doctoral research focuses on developing transferable and scalable methods for traffic estimation on residential roads using open data. His research interests include open data, open source tools, spatial analysis, sustainable transport, and transport planning and modelling.

 This instructor will host a course about Tools and Skills for Reproducible Transport Research

title: Kelly Clifton
text:
Kelly J. Clifton is a professor at the University of British Columbia, Canada, and an internationally-recognized expert on transport and land use interactions, travel behaviour, pedestrian modeling, and equity in transportation policy. She has worked to elevate public impact research through partnerships with public agencies and community groups. Previously, Kelly was Professor of Portland State University‚Äôs Civil and Environmental Engineering, an affiliate of the Urban Studies and Planning Program, and a Fellow in the Institute for Sustainable Solutions. In addition to her faculty appointments there, she served as the interim Associate Vice President for Research for the campus and was the former Associate Dean of Research for the Maseeh College of Engineering and Computer Science. She has also held faculty positions at the University of Maryland and University of Iowa. Kelly has a PhD in Community and Regional Planning from the University of Texas at Austin, MS in Planning from the University of Arizona, and BS in Mechanical Engineering from West Virginia University.

 This speaker will host a keynote on the 12th September

title: Michelle Poyourow
text:
Michelle Poyourow is the Principal Associate at Jarrett Walker + Associates, being a recognized transit planner with over 15 years of experience in bus network redesign, public engagement, and integrated land use and mobility policy. She specializes in managing complex transit projects‚Äîfrom large citywide network overhauls to rural service planning‚Äîwhile facilitating effective interagency collaboration and community input. Her background in political advocacy and policy gives her a unique edge in navigating the communication and governance aspects of transit planning. Michelle has managed transit network plans and redesigns for large and small cities including Dallas, Sacramento, and Atlanta. She is currently working on network studies in Wales and Long Island, NY.

 This speaker will host a keynote on the 11th September

title: Hannah Hook
text:
Hannah Hook is DTN Alumni and will soon start an Assistant Professor position of Sustainable Land Use and Transport Planning in the Department of the Built Environment at Aalto University, Finland. She completed her PhD and is currently a postdoctoral researcher at Ghent University, and previously completed two Master‚Äôs degrees in GIS Technology (University of Arizona) and Sustainable Cities (King‚Äôs College London) and two Bachelor‚Äôs degrees in Sustainability and Business Communications (Arizona State University). Her research focuses on the role of discretionary and undirected travel in promoting well-being, travel satisfaction, and transport equity. Hannah‚Äôs work bridges mobility behaviour, the built environment, and social sustainability.

 This speaker will host a keynote on the 11th September


 This instructor will host a course about Qualitative Methods in Urban Mobility Research

title: Ros√°rio Mac√°rio
text:
Ros√°rio Mac√°rio, has degrees in Business Economics, MSc and PhD in Transportation Systems, Habilitation (DSc) in Civil Engineering. She is Full Professor and Researcher specialized in Mobility and Accessibility at the Department of Civil Engineering, Architecture and Georresources at Instituto Superior T√©cnico (IST) Universidade de Lisboa and former Guest Professor at University of Antwerp, Department of Transport and Regional Economics (Belgium). Her urban mobility research focuses are: institutional setting, policy development and evaluation, Economics and financing. She stands for a systemic and integrated view of urban mobility systems, prioritising accessibility as a value and a strategic goal in any city or urban area. She acts as advisor of several governments and international investment agencies in Europe, South America and Africa.

 This instructor will host a course about Shared Mobility - Policy challenges and multimodal solutions

title: Andres Monzon
text:
Full Professor in Transportation Engineering since 2002, Civil Engineering Department of the Polytechnic University of Madrid, Spain, Andres Monzon founded the TRANSyT-Transport Research Center at the UPM in 2004, being its Director until 2017. He has been the Rector¬¥s Delegate for Sustainable Urban Mobility and Coordinator of the Research and Academic Cluster MoviTUR-Mobility of the Future since 2020. Prof.¬†Monzon promoted the Spanish Metropolitan Mobility Observatory and has been its Director since 2004. He founded the Spanish Forum of Transport Engineering and was its president from 2014 to 2023. Member of the Advisory Council of the Spanish Ministry of Transport and Sustainable Mobility since 2015.

 This instructor will host a course about Shared Mobility - Policy challenges and multimodal solutions

title: Robin Lovelace
text:
Robin Lovelace is a University Academic Fellow at the Leeds Institute for Transport Studies (ITS). He did his PhD in the Energy Costs of Commuting, leading to new methods for processing spatial and individual level data to generate scenarios of decarbonisation, leading to the open source books Spatial Microsimulation with R and, recently, Geocomputation with R. Robin has wide ranging experience modeling sustainable transport systems and visualizing transport futures. These skills have been applied on a number of projects with real-world applications, most recently as Lead Developer of the Propensity to Cycle Tool and the stplanr package for sustainable transport planning.

 This instructor will host a course about Tools and Skills for Reproducible Transport Research

title: David Vale
text:
David Vale is an associate professor in Lisbon School of Architecture, University of Lisbon, where he teaches Urban Geography, Road Systems and Transport, Geographic Information Systems and Contemporary Urban Challenges. He has completed his Ph.D.¬†in Architecture, Planning and Landscape at Newcastle University. David Vale has a bachelor in Geography and Regional Planning from Nova University of Lisbon, and a MSc in Geographic Information Systems from the Instituto Superior T√©cnico, University of Lisbon. His research is focused on urban and regional planning, specially in what concerns the integration of land use and transport, transit-oriented development (TOD), walkability, bikeability and accessibility measurement, and the relationships between the built environment and mobility patterns, physical activity and health.

 This speaker will host a keynote on the 11th September

title: Miguel Costa
text:
Miguel Costa is a postdoctoral researcher at the Technical University of Denmark, where he develops decision-support tools for climate adaptation policy making. His current work combines reinforcement learning and agent-based simulation to identify optimal sets or sequences of adaptation strategies. This framework aims to reveal dynamic links between flooding events, transport systems, public health, and wellbeing ‚Äì ultimately supporting decision-making that maximizes societal impact. Miguel holds a PhD (magna cum laude) in Transportation Systems and an MSc in Electrical Engineering from Instituto Superior T√©cnico. His research interests lie at the intersection of artificial intelligence and transport, focusing on how machine learning can be used to objectively characterize complex phenomena while also capturing individuals‚Äô subjective experiences. By bridging this gap, he aims to inform planning and policy decisions that are both data-driven and human-centered.

 This speaker will host a keynote on the 12th September

title: Zabe Bent
text:
Zabe Bent is an urban planner and designer with extensive experience in street design and sustainable mobility. She served as Director of Design at the National Association of City Transportation Officials (NACTO), where she led the development of street design guidelines and supported cities in implementing Complete Streets strategies in the U.S. Previously, she worked as a Transportation Planner at the San Francisco County Transportation Authority. She holds a Masters in City Planning and a Master of Science in Transportation from MIT, as well as a Bachelor of Arts from Columbia University.

 This speaker will host a keynote on the 11th September

title: Getting to Lisbon
text:
Lisbon international airport (Humberto Delgado Airport) connects the world with the city and has a direct connection to its transportation system, through the metro red line.



Lisbon airport

title: Getting to Lisbon
text:
Lisbon international airport (Humberto Delgado Airport) connects the world with the city and has a direct connection to its transportation system, through the metro red line.



Lisbon airport

title: Getting to Lisbon
text:
By train
Lisbon has two main stations for long distance services. Despite not having direct connections with foreign countries, if you come from anywhere in Portugal you can get here by picking a train with destination Lisboa Santa Apol√≥nia if you come from the north or Lisboa Oriente if you come from the south. Both stations are connected to the metro network and urban railway services.



Gare do Oriente Station

title: Getting to Lisbon
text:
By bus
An alternative to get to Lisbon are the long distance buses, covering Portugal mainland, Spain and even France. At Lisbon, they get to Sete Rios or Gare do Oriente. Both stations are connected to the metro network.



Sete Rios station

title: Getting to the venue
text:
The DTN Annual Forum 2025 will be hosted at Institute of Geography and Spatial Planning (IGOT). It is located in the University of Lisbon campus in heart of Lisbon city, accessible by several transport modes.
This page specifies the transport interfaces that are closest to the DTN venue. For more details on Lisbon transportation system network, apps and prices, refer to Getting around.

title: Getting to the venue
text:
By bike
IGOT is accessible through the city cycle lane infrastructure.
There is a station from the public bike system right outside the venue. Its number is 461 - Rua Professor Teresa Ambr√≥sio. Find the stations map at GIRA website.
You can also park an e-scooter or any other shared mobility vehicle right outside. They are allowed inside the campus.

title: Getting to the venue
text:
By train/metro
IGOT is just a 15 minutes walk from Entrecampos interface. There you can catch an urban train to almost anywhere in Lisbon metropolitan area.
This interface also connects to metro. There you can catch the yellow line and easily connect to the others (2 stations away from green and red lines, 4 from the blue line).
Regarding metro, the stippness of the terrain in this area makes Entrecampos a better option to leave the venue. To get there, Cidade Universit√°ria metro station is a better option.

title: Getting to the venue
text:
By bus
IGOT is served by several lines of the urban bus operator, Carris, connecting to almost anywhere in the city: 701, 731, 732, 735, 738, 754, 755, 764 and 768.
There is also a suburban bus that serves it, 3702 from operator Carris Metropolitana, connecting to Almada, in the south bank of Lisbon metro area.






IGOT building has a GIRA (public bike system) station next to it







You can also park any shared mobility vehicle right outside









Entrecampos train/metro interface is a 15 minutes walk from the venue

title: Getting around
text: Lisbon is serviced by a robust transportation system, build up on metro, bus, trams and urban trains. Here we list the main means of transportation and how you can use them.

title: Getting around
text:
Means of transportation




Walking
The best way to get around the city. Get on your feet and explore!



Cycling
Lisbon has 128km of dedicated cycle lanes. Discover the network at ciclovias.pt!  You can ride them using the public bike system, GIRA. It has a fee of only 2‚Ç¨/day, including unlimited trips up to 30 minutes (+2‚Ç¨ per 45-90‚Äô). Download the app and get a bike here!



Metro
Metro is the quickest way to cover distances inside the city. Find out more at Metro de Lisboa website.



Bus/tram/lift
Buses cover the entire city, complementing the metro network for less dense areas accessibility. Trams and lifts allow you to discover the city hills and Bel√©m. Discover the network at Carris website.

title: Getting around
text:
Tickets

 Every participant will be provided with a 10‚Ç¨ Zapping card on the first day of the event.

Trips can be payed with contactless cards, being charged the same amount as for the board ticket. However, you can buy a Zapping card (0,50‚Ç¨ per card, one card per person) at the Metro machines and top it up with 3, 5 or 10‚Ç¨. Using this card, the individual trips are cheaper on buses and trams.

title: Getting around
text:
Apps
Below you can find some apps that integrate information about Lisbon transportation system, allowing you to find the best route and track vehicles in real time!

title: Venue
text:
The DTN Annual Forum 2025 will be hosted at Institute of Geography and Spatial Planning (IGOT). It is located in the heart of Lisbon city and inside University of Lisbon campus, accessible by several transport modes. For more details on how to get to Lisbon, to the venue and around the city, check the respective pages.


Floor plan
Check-in is performed in the ground floor, right at the entrance of the building. Talks, discusions and courses will take place on the 1st floor. The garden outside will also host some activities, coffee breaks and lunches. Refer to the schedule for more details.


Ground floor



Upper floor

title: Guides
text:
Lisbon is more than a city. It is a broad and whole territory waiting to be explored. In this page we share with you some touristic guides that may be of your interest.








  




Turismo de Lisboa







Website




The institutional page for Lisboa tourism association. Here you can find several informations about the main attractions, events and practical tips.






https://www.visitlisboa.com/en






  




Visit a city







App




This app provides several itineraries addapted to diverse preferences and durations.






https://www.visitacity.com/en/lisbon






  




TimeOut







Website




This magazine compiles several guides that can help you find the best viewpoints, museums or beaches.
